variant.question: If a crew member reports for duty at 05:35, their first departure occurs at 06:35, and the maximum duty period for the day is stated to be 12 hours 45 minutes. What time should the aircraft be back on stand and how late can this be extended to using the commander's discretion?

options.text: 17:20, extended to 18:20
19:20, extended to 21:20.
18:20, extended to 19:00.
18:20, extended to 20:20.

variant.question: A pilot working for a CAT Operator has performed 185 duty hours in the last 27 consecutive days. On the 28th day, the Operator’s crewing department calls asking the pilot to operate a flight with a total duty of 8 hours later that same day. What would be the correct decision, according to the EU Regulation on Air Operations?

options.text: Operate the flight, since duty is limited to 200 hours in any 28 consecutive days.
Operate the flight, since duty is limited to 195 hours in any 28 consecutive days.
NOT operate the flight, since duty shall NOT exceed 190 hours in any 28 consecutive days.
NOT operate the flight, since duty shall NOT exceed 100 hours in any 28 consecutive days.

variant.question: What is the maximum flight duty period (FDP) without extensions?

options.text: 13 hours.
15 hours.
11 hours.
10 hours.

variant.question: An aircraft is approaching its destination and the landing is planned to take place within 30 minutes. The flight crew have 1 hour left until they reach their maximum daily Flight Duty Period (FDP). Suddenly the Commander receives a message from the Operator asking him/her to divert to another destination for maintenance purposes. Reaching this destination would take 2 hours from the present position of the aircraft, thus exceeding the maximum daily FDP for the flight crew. Could this diversion be performed?

options.text: No, because the maximum allowable extension of the daily FDP is 30 minutes, which will not be enough to perform this diversion.
No, the maximum daily FDP may not be exceeded, so the aeroplane must continue to it's planned destination.
Yes, the Operator can always order the flight crew to exceed the maximum FDP, at their discretion.
Yes, the Commander may increase the daily FDP if unforeseen circumstances arise, in consultation with the crew.

variant.question: A pilot has a total duty period of 180 hours in the last 27 days, he/she has a 8 hours duty period scheduled for the 28th. He/she can:

options.text: Not fly because the maximum duty period is 100 hours in 28 days.
Fly because the maximum duty period is 200 hours in 28 days.
Fly because the maximum duty period is 190 hours in 28 days.
Not fly because you can’t fly 185 hours in 28 days.

variant.question: As a flight crew member, you are to report for a period of airport standby. When does the airport standby period commence?

options.text: From reporting at the reporting point.
From arriving at the airport.
30 minutes before arriving at the airport.
45 minutes before arriving at the airport.

variant.question: The maximum flight duty time in any 7 consecutive days:
What is the maximum flight duty period (FDP), including any extensions, if a crew member is acclimatised to the time zone and if a commercial air transport operation has to be considered?

options.text: 13 hours
12 hours
15 hours
14 hours

variant.question: \`Night duty\` is a duty period encroaching any portion of the period, in the time zone to which the crew is acclimatised, between..

options.text: 00:30 and 04:30 hours.
02:00 and 04:59 hours.
01:00 and 05:00 hours.
00:00 and 06:00 hours.

variant.question: When does the standby duty time of a crew member start to count?

options.text: At the arrival at the airport.
When reporting at the reporting point.
30 minutes before arrival at the airport.
45 minutes before arrival at the airport.

variant.question: En-route to the destination, with only one hour left until the limit on flight duty is reached, and 30 min to reach the destination, the operator contacts you and tells you to divert to an alternate 2 hours away for unforeseen circumstance. Are you allowed?

options.text: No, never.

Yes, the commander can choose to extend the FDT for unforeseen circumstances and

he/she shall consult all crew members on their alertness levels.
Yes, provided that approval from the authority is obtained.
No, the commander can only extend the FDT in case of emergency.

variant.question: The minimum rest period for flight crew before undertaking a Flight Duty Period (FDP) away from the home base is..

options.text: at least as long as the preceding duty period, or 10 hours, whichever is greater.
8 hours.
at least as long as the preceding duty period, or 13 hours, whichever is greater.
the preceding duty period, or 12 hours, whichever is less.

variant.question: The FDP was extended to 9 hours. Provided that the crew is at their home base and the operator is not providing accommodation, when can the next flight duty commence?

options.text: 12 hours
10 hours
9 hours
14 hours

variant.question: Consider the European Regulation on Air Operations as applicable to Commercial Air Transport operations. Flight time specification schemes shall state the conditions for extensions to the maximum basic daily FDP due to in-flight rest. These extensions shall take into account the..

options.text: maximum in-flight rest allocated to each crew member.
discretion of the competent authority.
type of aircraft operated, regardless of the type of in-flight rest facilities.
augmentation of the basic flight crew.

variant.question: The minimum rest period for flight crew before undertaking a Flight Duty Period (FDP) at home base is at least ... hours.
The total flight time of the sectors on which an individual crew member is assigned as an operating crew member shall not exceed:

options.text: 900 hours of flight time in any 14 consecutive days.
100 hours of flight time in any 40 consecutive days.
700 hours of flight time in any calender year.
900 hours of flight time in any calendar year.

variant.question: A pilot working for a CAT operator has performed 105 duty hours in the last 13 consecutive days. On the 14th day, the operator's crewing department calls, asking the pilot to operate a flight with a total duty of 8 hours later that same day. According to the EU-OPS regulations, what is the correct decision?

options.text: Operate the flight, since the limit for duty is 120 duty hours in any 14 consecutive days.
Operate the flight, since the limit for duty is 115 duty hours in any 14 consecutive days.
NOT operate the flight, since duty shall NOT exceed 110 duty hours in any 14 consecutive days.
NOT operating the flight, since duty shall NOT exceed 105 duty hours in any 14 consecutive days.

variant.question: The total duty period to which a crew member may be assigned shall not exceed..

options.text: 100 hours in any 28 consecutive days.
190 duty hours in any 30 consecutive days.
110 duty hours in any 15 consecutive days.
60 duty hours in any 7 consecutive days.

variant.question: A crew member is positioned to another airport from which it will operate. When does the duty period start?

options.text: 30 minutes before landing.
After landing.
When positioning starts.
On the flight back.

variant.question: According to ICAO Annex 6, the definition of "flight time" is for the purpose of defining or describing..

options.text: flight and duty time regulations.
airborne time.
if a flight is to be considered a cross-country flight.
when the MEL cannot be applied.

variant.question: A duty with a report time of 08:15 has been scheduled for a pilot. This two-sector duty is using a planned extension of 1 hour, increasing the maximum Flight Duty Period (FDP) from 13 hours to 14 hours. The aeroplane is scheduled to land back at its home base at 21:55\. Which of the following completes the statement correctly. Considering that all times are local and all crew members are acclimatised, the duty is planned:

options.text: 40 minutes inside Commander's discretion and the latest time the aeroplane must park is 00:15.
40 minutes inside Commander's discretion and the latest time the aeroplane must park is 23:15.
Within 20 minutes of the maximum FDP and the latest time the aeroplane must park using all available Commander's discretion is at 00:15.
Within 20 minutes of the maximum FDP and the latest time the aeroplane must park using all available Commander's discretion is at 23:15.
